issues.description: In the problem statement text (Part 2, description of the controller methods) the parameter type is described as Consumer<List<Note>> (mentions Note) even though the methods being discussed are for persons and the template uses Consumer<List<Person>>. This is an internal documentation/type mention mismatch that can confuse students about the expected callback type for PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods so the narrative matches the template code and UML. This keeps documentation and code consistent and avoids confusion.

issues.description: The solution repository's PersonScene (view) includes a direct import and field for PersonService (view holding a service reference), which contradicts the described MVC separation in the problem statement and the template (the view should interact with the controller, not directly with services). This introduces a structural violation of the intended architecture and may confuse students examining the reference solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Remove the PersonService import and the personService field from the solution view (PersonScene). Ensure the view only interacts with the PersonController as in the template and the MVC diagram. If the service reference is unused, delete it; if it was added unintentionally, restore MVC separation so the solution matches the intended architecture.

issues.description: The problem statement incorrectly refers to the callback parameter type for PersonController methods as Consumer<List<Note>> while both the template and the solution use Consumer<List<Person>>. This mixes the Note and Person concepts and can confuse students about the expected type and behavior of the controller callbacks (are they supposed to handle Note lists or Person lists?).
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods and their callback parameter. This makes the description consistent with the template and solution and avoids mixing the Note and Person concepts.
